Introduction

Fournier gangrene is a life-threatening, rapidly-spreading form of necrotizing fasciitis that involves the perineal, perianal, and genital areas.  It is typically a polymicrobial infection that spreads quickly along fascial planes and causes ischemia and necrosis of the soft tissues; it can quickly lead to sepsis and death without intervention.  Presenting symptoms include severe perineal/genital pain out of proportion to examination.  Fever, crepitus, bullae, and hypotension develop as the infection progresses.  Treatment includes immediate surgical intervention for debridement of gangrenous tissue and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Risk factors

Risk factors for Fournier gangrene include:

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Obesity
  • Immunosuppression
  • Male sex (10:1 male-to-female ratio)
  • Age >50
  • Alcohol dependence
  • Genitourinary tract infection (eg, perirectal abscess)
  • Perineal trauma or surgery (eg, prostate biopsy)

Pathophysiology

Most cases of Fournier gangrene arise from cutaneous breakdown in the perineal, perianal, or genital regions, which creates a portal of entry for polymicrobial colonic or urogenital organisms.  Infection typically includes a mixture of aerobic (eg, group A streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus), anaerobic (eg, Bacteroides, Clostridium), and facultative organisms that can live in aerobic or anaerobic conditions (eg, Escherichia coli, enterococci).

Bacterial toxins and enzymes induce inflammation, tissue destruction, and microthrombosis of subcutaneous blood vessels, leading to ischemia and necrosis of the skin, subcutaneous fat, and fascia.  The infection spreads rapidly via fascial planes, quickly involving surrounding structures (eg, gluteus muscles, abdominal wall), and dissemination into the bloodstream results in sepsis and septic shock.

Clinical presentation

Manifestations of Fournier gangrene typically arise rapidly and include the following:

  • Severe pain, often out of proportion to examination findings:  Early tissue destruction is subcutaneous and overlying skin may appear relatively unremarkable.
  • Chills, malaise, myalgia
  • Paresthesia/sensory loss may occur due to necrosis of superficial subcutaneous nerves.
  • Onset is often abrupt and progression may occur within hours to several days.

Examination findings include:

  • Tenderness, edema, induration, and erythema in the perineum, scrotum/labia, perianal region, and/or lower abdomen
  • Crepitus:  palpable air in the soft tissues related to gas-forming organisms (eg, Clostridium)
  • Bullae (large blister), foul smelling discharge, darkly discolored skin:  indicates cutaneous necrosis
  • Systemic symptoms such as fever, tachycardia
  • Septic shock:  progression of disease that leads to hypotension, multiorgan failure, and death

Diagnosis

The diagnosis of Fournier gangrene is primarily clinical and should be suspected in any patient with a perineal/genital soft tissue infection, systemic symptoms (eg, fever, shock), and any of the following:

  • Pain out of proportion to examination
  • Rapidly progressive illness
  • Evidence of necrosis (eg, bullae) or soft tissue gas (eg, crepitus)

Characteristic clinical findings may be absent or mild in the early stages of disease, making this a challenging diagnosis.  A high index of clinical suspicion, especially in high-risk patients (eg, those with diabetes mellitus), is required to prevent overlooking or misdiagnosing the condition.

Differential diagnosis

  • Cellulitis (
    image 1
    ):  Bacterial infection causes erythema, warmth, edema, and tenderness of the deep dermis and subcutaneous fat.  It may appear similar to early Fournier gangrene, but the course is usually indolent.  Rapidly advancing infection, severe pain, septic shock, and crepitus are not typical.
  • Abscess (eg, perianal, labial) (
    image 2
    ):  A well-defined collection of pus presents as a localized, tender, fluctuant mass within the soft tissue.  It can cause soft tissue erythema and edema, but extensive tissue necrosis and systemic toxicity are rare.
  • Infected Bartholin cyst (
    figure 1
    ):  Infection of a vaginal Bartholin gland can cause a painful, fluctuant mass in the vulvar region, but it typically lacks the rapid progression and soft tissue destruction associated with Fournier gangrene.

Imaging

Imaging can delay surgical intervention and is generally not recommended when the presentation is highly suspicious for Fournier gangrene (eg, crepitus, rapid progression), especially if there is hemodynamic instability.  These patients require immediate surgical exploration and debridement.

In patients with suspected Fournier gangrene whose condition is hemodynamically stable, a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis may be appropriate.  CT scan findings  (eg, soft tissue air) can help confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of tissue involvement (

image 3
).  However, a negative CT scan does not rule out the diagnosis.  Direct visualization of the soft tissue during surgery is the only way to definitively confirm the presence or absence of a necrotizing infection.  If suspicion remains despite a normal CT scan, surgical consultation is warranted.

Laboratory evaluation

In Fournier gangrene, most laboratory findings are nonspecific, but the following abnormalities may be observed:

  • Leukocytosis is associated with inflammation/infection.
  • Metabolic acidosis (often lactic acidosis due to soft tissue hypoxia), elevated creatinine, and elevated transaminates suggest septic shock with multiorgan injury.
  • Elevated procalcitonin, C-reactive protein, and lactic acid are indicators of sepsis/septic shock.
  • High creatinine kinase levels imply breakdown/necrosis involving the fascia or muscle.
  • Positive blood and wound cultures typically reveal polymicrobial infection.

Management

Fournier gangrene is a surgical emergency, and any delay in operative intervention dramatically increases the risk for morbidity and mortality.  Definitive management includes immediate surgical debridement to remove necrotic tissue and to control the spread of infection.  Important adjunctive treatments include broad-spectrum antibiotics, targeting aerobic and anaerobic organisms, and hemodynamic support with IV fluids and/or vasopressors.

Prognosis

The prognosis of Fournier gangrene depends on the promptness of diagnosis, adequacy of surgical debridement, and overall patient health status.  Despite advances in medical care, Fournier gangrene is associated with significant morbidity and mortality.  Immediate surgical intervention is essential to minimize tissue loss and to prevent systemic toxicity and death.  Patients with diabetes mellitus, elderly patients, and those with extensive necrosis or shock on initial presentation tend to have a worse prognosis.

Summary

Fournier gangrene is a necrotizing soft tissue infection that involves the perineal, perianal, and genital areas and usually occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus and obesity (
